moves.1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bc4 Nf6 4. Ng5 d5: I'm going to guess that this was an oversight.
moves.7... Nxe4: black will win a piece, but must be very alert.  a similar sacrifice was played by Bronstein in '56 and his opponent missed the best continuation and white's pawns became too active for black to handle.
active play is necessary here or black could get steamrolled by those pawns
moves.12. Nc3: this isn't active enough.  white had to try 12 Qh5+ with a complicated game.
moves.12... O-O: being willing to let that pawn go to get the king into safety.
moves.13. a3 a6 14. b3 Bd7 15. Bb2 b6 16. exf5: hereabouts black starts to take control of the board
moves.21. Qd3 Nb7 22. b4 Rc4: a powerful positional move which slaps a bind on white
moves.23. Rfe1 Qf7 24. Re2: not falling for 24 Bxe5 Bxe5 25 Rxe5 Qxf2+ 26 Kh1 Rxf2!! mating.
moves.24... e4 25. Qd1 Bf4 26. Ra1 Nd6: at last the knight has made its way to a good square
moves.27. Bc1 Rfc8 28. Bxf4 Qxf4 29. Ra2 Qe5 3: forcing the win of the "d" pawn
moves.31. Rd2 Rxd2 32. Qxd2 Nc4 33. Qd1 Rd8 34: some analysis revealed this is the most efficient way to put white away.
moves.36. Qh4: I was surprised white would allow a passed pawn like that.  after 36 fxe3 Nxe3 black had intended ... Qd4.  the plan was to take the queens off the board and win the pawns on the queenside.
moves.36... e2: white can defend himself after the direct ... Qd1+
moves.37. f3: this makes it easy.  f4 was necessary.  the key difference is that black wouldn't have the winning check on d6.
moves.37... Qd1+ 38. Qe1: to 38 Kh2 I had plannedf 38 ... Re8 39 Qh5 Qd6+ forcing the queening of the pawn
